post.title: Week 11 — Roots, Interpolation, Curve fitting
post.content:
Finding Roots of a function

Roots of a function

  • A root or zero of a function f(x)f(x)f(x) is a solution of the equation f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0

  • Some functions can be solved in closed form i.e., their solutions can be represented in terms of functions that we know.

    • f(x)=x2−1f(x) = x^2 - 1f(x)=x2−1 can be factored to (x−1)(x+1)(x-1)(x+1)(x−1)(x+1), with the solution of f(x)=0f(x) = 0f(x)=0 being x=−1,1x = -1, 1x=−1,1

  • For the functions that cannot be factored or represented in closed form, we must use numerical methods to find their roots.

    • See this post for more information.

  • In general, finding roots numerically involves a procedure which generates a sequence of approximations x1,x2,...,xnx_1, x_2, ..., x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​ until we obtain a value close to the actual root.

  • Note that we will focus on finding the real roots to functions, not the complex roots

Single and double roots

  • The equation f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0 has a single root for each x-intercept i.e. each time the function f(x)f(x)f(x) crosses X-axis
  • Double roots (two equal roots) occur when f(x)f(x)f(x) touches but does not cross the X-axis
    • For example, f(x)=x2f(x) = x^2f(x)=x2 has a double root

Methods of finding roots

  • All the methods we will see require an initial estimate of the root — either a single number as an estimate or an estimated interval containing the root.

  • Few different ways of estimating a root value or interval:

    • If the equation is associated with a physical problem its physical context may suggest the estimate.
    • A search can be carried out for estimated root values.
    • The function could be plotted (a visual procedure).

  • We will see the following methods in this lecture:

    • Bisection method
    • Secant method
    • Newton-Raphson method

Intermediate value theorem

  • Let f(x)f(x)f(x) be a continuous function on the interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] and let sss be a number where f(a)<s<f(b)f(a) < s < f(b)f(a)<s<f(b), then there exists at least one xxx with f(x)=sf(x) = sf(x)=s.

  • Note: we will assume that all functions are continuous for root finding algorithms

  • We will use this theorem in some of our methods

  • The main idea is that

    • If f(a)f(a)f(a) and f(b)f(b)f(b) have opposite signs, e.g. f(a)<0<f(b)f(a) < 0 < f(b)f(a)<0<f(b), then there is at least one xxx in the interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] such that f(x)=s=0f(x) = s = 0f(x)=s=0 i.e. there exists a root in [a,b][a, b][a,b]

  • Note that since a double root does not lead to a change in sign, it won’t be detectable using this method.

Checking if an interval contains a root

Given a function f(x)f(x)f(x) which is continuous in the interval [a,b][a, b][a,b], if f(a)f(a)f(a) and f(b)f(b)f(b) have opposite signs, we have a root in [a,b][a, b][a,b]

def f(x): return x ** 2 - 25 a1, b1 = [-4.0, 3.0] print('Is root in [-4.0, 3.0]?', f(a1) * f(b1) < 0) # False a2, b2 = [3.0, 10.0] print('Is root in [3.0, 10.0]?', f(a2) * f(b2) < 0) # True

Example

  • Since we have tantantan function, which is not continuous, there are sign changes at discontinuities, e.g. in interval [1,2][1, 2][1,2].
  • So the theorem doesn’t work here and we can’t use the root finding methods in the interval [1,2][1, 2][1,2].
  • But we can find root in the interval [6,7][6, 7][6,7].

Bisection method

  • It is the simplest root finding algorithm which can be applied to any continuous function f(x)f(x)f(x) on an interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] where a root exists i.e. f(a)f(a)f(a) and f(b)f(b)f(b) have different signs.

  • Therefore, the method relies on Intermediate value theorem.

  • The general idea is to repeat the following

    • Divide the interval in two subintervals, one of which must contain the root.
    • Select the subinterval [an,bn][a_n, b_n][an​,bn​] where f(x)f(x)f(x) changes sign i.e. f(an)⋅f(bn)<0f(a_n)·f(b_n) < 0f(an​)⋅f(bn​)<0

Algorithm

  1. Choose an interval [a0,b0][a_0, b_0][a0​,b0​] where sign of f(x)f(x)f(x) changes i.e. f(a0)⋅f(b0)<0f(a_0) \cdot f(b_0) < 0f(a0​)⋅f(b0​)<0

  2. Compute f(m0)f(m_0)f(m0​) for the midpoint m0=a0+b02m_0 = \frac{a_0 + b_0}{2}m0​=2a0​+b0​​

  3. Determine the next subinterval [a1,b1][a_1, b_1][a1​,b1​] as follows:

    • If f(a0)⋅f(m0)<0f(a_0) \cdot f(m_0) < 0f(a0​)⋅f(m0​)<0, then [a1,b1]=[a0,m0][a_1, b_1] = [a_0, m_0][a1​,b1​]=[a0​,m0​]
    • If f(m0)⋅f(b0)<0f(m_0) \cdot f(b_0) < 0f(m0​)⋅f(b0​)<0, then [a1,b1]=[m0,b0][a_1, b_1] = [m_0, b_0][a1​,b1​]=[m0​,b0​]

  4. Repeat steps (2) and (3) until the interval [an,bn][a_n, b_n][an​,bn​] is small enough, i.e. its size is less than some value ϵ\epsilonϵ

  5. Return the midpoint value mn=an+bn2m_n = \frac{a_n + b_n}{2}mn​=2an​+bn​​

To visualize this algorithm download visualize_bisection.py from myCourse and run it.

Python implementation

def bisection(f, a, b, epsilon): while abs(a - b) > epsilon: # until interval is small mid = (a + b) / 2 f_mid = f(mid) # Choose one of the two subintervals if f(a) * f_mid < 0: b = mid elif f(b) * f_mid < 0: a = mid elif abs(f_mid) < epsilon: # Check if f(mid) is very close to zero return mid # Found root else: return None # Root is not in the interval # Return midpoint as a good approximation to the root return (a + b) / 2

Example

f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752f(x) = x^4 - 6.4x^3 + 6.45x^2 + 20.538x - 31.752f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752

We have a double root at x=2x=2x=2 and single root at x=4x=4x=4.

from rootfinding import bisection def f(x): return x ** 4 - 6.4 * x ** 3 + 6.45 * x ** 2 + 20.538 * x - 31.752 epsilon = 0.0001 # The single root is found because the interval [-1.0, 5.0] contains it. print(bisection(f, -1.0, 5.0, epsilon)) # 4.0000152587890625 # The double root at 2.0 cannot be not found by bisection method # because function does not change sign in the interval [-1.0, 3.0]. print(bisection(f, -1.0, 3.0, epsilon)) # None

Secant Method

  • A secant line is a straight line joining at least two points on a function.

  • The secant method is very similar to the bisection method.

  • Instead of choosing the midpoint, the secant method divides each interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] by the x-intercept of the secant line connecting the endpoints (a,f(a))(a, f(a))(a,f(a)) and (b,f(b))(b, f(b))(b,f(b)).

  • However, unlike Bisection method, Secant method does not require that a root be present in the interval [a,b][a, b][a,b]. So the Secant method may not converge to any number.

Formula for Secant line

  • Let f(x)f(x)f(x) be a continuous function on a closed interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] such that f(a)⋅f(b)<0f(a) \cdot f(b) < 0f(a)⋅f(b)<0

  • The secant line connecting the endpoints (a,f(a))(a, f(a))(a,f(a)) and (b,f(b))(b, f(b))(b,f(b)) is given by

    y=f(b)−f(a)b−a(x−a)+f(a)y = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}(x - a) + f(a)y=b−af(b)−f(a)​(x−a)+f(a)

  • By setting y=0y=0y=0 in above equation, we get the x-intercept of secant line as follows:

    x=a−f(a)b−af(b)−f(a)x = a - f(a) \frac{b - a}{f(b) - f(a)}x=a−f(a)f(b)−f(a)b−a​

Algorithm for Secant method

  • Choose an interval [a0,b0][a_0, b_0][a0​,b0​] where sign of f(x)f(x)f(x) changes i.e. f(a0)⋅f(b0)<0f(a_0) \cdot f(b_0) < 0f(a0​)⋅f(b0​)<0.

  • Compute f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​) where x0x_0x0​ is the x-intercept of secant line between (a0,f(a0))(a_0, f(a_0))(a0​,f(a0​)) and (b0,f(b0))(b_0, f(b_0))(b0​,f(b0​)) given by

    x0=a0−f(a0)b0−a0f(b0)−f(a0)x_0 = a_0 - f(a_0) \frac{b_0 - a_0}{f(b_0) - f(a_0)}x0​=a0​−f(a0​)f(b0​)−f(a0​)b0​−a0​​

  • Determine the next subinterval [a1,b1][a_1, b_1][a1​,b1​] as follows:

    • If f(a0)⋅f(x0)<0f(a_0) \cdot f(x_0) < 0f(a0​)⋅f(x0​)<0, then [a1,b1]=[a0,x0][a_1, b_1] = [a_0, x_0][a1​,b1​]=[a0​,x0​]
    • If f(x0)⋅f(b0)<0f(x_0) \cdot f(b_0) < 0f(x0​)⋅f(b0​)<0, then [a1,b1]=[x0,b0][a_1, b_1] = [x_0, b_0][a1​,b1​]=[x0​,b0​]

  • Repeat steps (2) and (3) until the interval [an,bn][a_n, b_n][an​,bn​] is small enough or some fixed number of steps have been taken.

  • Return the value xnx_nxn​, the x-intercept of nthn^{th}nth subinterval.

To visualize this algorithm download visualize_secant.py from myCourse and run it.

Python implementation

def secant(f, a, b, num_iter, epsilon): for i in range(num_iter): slope = (f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a) x_sec = a - f(a) / slope # x-intercept of secant f_xsec = f(x_sec) if f(a) * f_xsec < 0: b = x_sec elif f(b) * f_xsec < 0: a = x_sec elif abs(f_xsec) < epsilon: return x_sec # Found root return a - f(a) / slope

Example

f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752f(x) = x^4 - 6.4x^3 + 6.45x^2 + 20.538x - 31.752f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752

We have a double root at x=2x=2x=2 and single root at x=4x=4x=4.

from rootfinding import secant # We have a double root at x = 2 and single root at x = 4 def f(x): return x**4 - 6.4*x**3 + 6.45*x**2 + 20.538*x - 31.752 num_iter = 100 epsilon = 1e-6 # The single root x = 4 is found because the interval [3.0, 6.0] contains it. print(secant(f, 3.0, 6.0, num_iter, epsilon)) # 3.9999999832440336 # Single root x = 4 is also found when interval is close to it but # does not contain the root. print(secant(f, 3.0, 3.8, num_iter*100, epsilon)) # 3.999999999999997 # Secant method is not guaranteed to find a double root x = 2. # For the interval to [-1.0, 3.0] it does not work. print(secant(f, -1.0, 3.0, num_iter*1000, epsilon)) # 3.450104190784905

Newton-Raphson method

  • Simple, fast, and best-known method of finding roots.

  • It uses derivative of the function f(x)f(x)f(x) i.e. tangent line.

    • So, it can only be used if the function is differentiable in the given interval.

    • If it is costly to compute the derivative, Newton’s method will be slow.

  • It doesn’t need an interval as an initial estimate, but only one estimate value x0x_0x0​.

  • We start with an approximation of the root, x0x_0x0​ and compute successive approximations as follows:

    xn=xn−1−f(xn−1)f′(xn−1)x_n = x_{n-1} - \frac{f(x_{n-1})}{f'(x_{n-1})}xn​=xn−1​−f′(xn−1​)f(xn−1​)​

  • The above formula comes from Taylor series approximation of f(xn)f(x_n)f(xn​) given by:

    f(xn)≈f(xn−1)+f′(xn−1)(xn−xn−1)f(x_n) \approx f(x_{n-1}) + f'(x_{n-1})(x_n - x_{n-1})f(xn​)≈f(xn−1​)+f′(xn−1​)(xn​−xn−1​)
    • Setting f(xn)f(x_n)f(xn​) to 000 and solving for xnx_nxn​ would give the above formula for xnx_nxn​.

  • This method may not converge. To prevent an infinite loop, we use a fixed number of iterations, and stop if we do not find a root.

To visualize this algorithm download visualize_newton.py from myCourse and run it.

Python implementation

def newton_raphson(f, df, x0, num_iter, epsilon): x = x0 for i in range(num_iter): f_x = f(x) if abs(f_x) < epsilon: # check if f_x is very close to zero return x # Found root x = x - f_x / df(x) # Return the best approximation we got so far. return x

Example

For Newton-Raphson we also need the first derivative of the function,

f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752f(x) = x^4 - 6.4x^3 + 6.45x^2 + 20.538x - 31.752f(x)=x4−6.4x3+6.45x2+20.538x−31.752
f′(x)=4x3−19.2x2+12.9x+20.538f'(x) = 4 x^3 - 19.2 x^2 + 12.9 x + 20.538f′(x)=4x3−19.2x2+12.9x+20.538
from rootfinding import newton_raphson # We have a double root at x = 2 and single root at x = 4 def f(x): return x ** 4 - 6.4 * x ** 3 + 6.45 * x ** 2 + 20.538 * x - 31.752 def df(x): return 4 * x ** 3 - 19.2 * x ** 2 + 12.9 * x + 20.538 num_iter = 100 epsilon = 1e-5 # error tolerance # Initial estimate x0 = 5.0 gives the single root 4.0 print(newton_raphson(f, df, 5.0, num_iter, epsilon)) # 4.000000289602415 # Initial estimate x0 = 0.0 gives the double root 2.0 # but convergence is slow and not guaranteed print(newton_raphson(f, df, 0.0, num_iter*1000, epsilon)) # 2.0994091782525763

Newton-Raphson divergence examples

Although the Newton–Raphson method converges fast near the root, its global convergence characteristics are poor.

Comparison of root-finding methods

MethodAssumptionsConvergenceCan find Double roots?
Bisectionfff is continuous, root exists in the initial intervalYesNo
Secantfff is continuous, root need not exist in the initial intervalNot guaranteed but will converge if root is close to initial interval.Not guaranteed.
Newton-Raphsonfff is continuous and differentiableNot guaranteed, but will converge if initial estimate is close to root.Yes but may converge slowly.

Speed of convergence when finding single roots:

  • Newton-Raphson > Secant > Bisection

Root-finding using Scipy

scipy is a library for scientific computing; we can install it in Thonny using Tool -> Manage packages.

from scipy import optimize def f(x): return x ** 4 - 6.4 * x ** 3 + 6.45 * x ** 2 + 20.538 * x - 31.752 def df(x): return 4 * x ** 3 - 19.2 * x ** 2 + 12.9 * x + 20.538 # Single root x=4 root = optimize.newton(f, x0=5.0, fprime=df, tol=1e-08, maxiter=50) print(root) # 4.000000000000001 # Double root x=2 root = optimize.newton(f, x0=1.0, fprime=df, tol=1e-08, maxiter=50) print(root) # 2.1000000354063086 # Uses secant method, when fprime argument is not given root = optimize.newton(f, x0=5.0, tol=1e-08, maxiter=50) print(root) # 4.000000000000001

Interpolation and Curve fitting

Motivation

  • We often want to analyze data points in the form shown below, where we have some dependent variables yiy_iyi​ corresponding to some independent variables xix_ixi​.
x0x_0x0​
x1x_1x1​
x2x_2x2​
.........
xnx_nxn​
y0y_0y0​
y1y_1y1​
y2y_2y2​
.........
yny_nyn​
  • The goal is to find a function f(x)f(x)f(x) that either
    • passes through all the points exactly (interpolation)
    • approximates data in a “best” possible way but not exactly (curve fitting)

Image from Kiusalaas, chap. 3.

How interpolation and curve-fitting are useful?

  • If we can find a function f(x)f(x)f(x) that interpolates or approximates the data well,
    • We can try to predict new data points (xk,yk)(x_k, y_k)(xk​,yk​).
    • We can better understand the underlying process that might have generated the data.

Polynomial interpolation

  • The simplest form of interpolation function is a polynomial function.
  • It is always possible to construct a polynomial P(x)P(x)P(x) of degree nnn that passes through n+1n+1n+1 data points.

Lagrange’s method

  • Suppose we have a dataset of n+1n+1n+1 points:

    (x0,y0),(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)(x_0, y_0), (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ..., (x_n, y_n)(x0​,y0​),(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)

  • We construct an interpolation polynomial of degree nnn, called the Lagrange polynomial, using the formula:

    P(x)=c0(x)y0+c1(x)y1+...+cn(x)ynP(x) = c_0(x)y_0 + c_1(x)y_1 + ... + c_n(x)y_nP(x)=c0​(x)y0​+c1​(x)y1​+...+cn​(x)yn​

    where ci(x)c_i(x)ci​(x) are called the cardinal functions.

  • The cardinal functions are given by:

    ci(x)=(x−x0)(xi−x0)⋯(x−xi−1)(xi−xi−1)⋅(x−xi+1)(xi−xi+1)⋯(x−xn)(xi−xn)=∏j=0j≠in(x−xj)(xi−xj)\begin{aligned} c_i\left( x \right) &= \frac{(x-x_0)}{(x_i-x_0)} \cdots \frac{(x-x_{i-1})}{(x_i-x_{i-1})} \cdot \frac{(x-x_{i+1})}{(x_i-x_{i+1})} \cdots \frac{(x-x_{n})}{(x_i-x_{n})}\\[1em] &= \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} \end{aligned}ci​(x)​=(xi​−x0​)(x−x0​)​⋯(xi​−xi−1​)(x−xi−1​)​⋅(xi​−xi+1​)(x−xi+1​)​⋯(xi​−xn​)(x−xn​)​=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(x−xj​)​​
    • Numerator contains all terms except (x−xi)(x - x_i)(x−xi​)
    • Denominator contains all terms except (xi−xi)(x_i - x_i)(xi​−xi​)

Claim: P(x)P(x)P(x) passes through each data point

If P(x)P(x)P(x) passes through all points (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​), then we must have:

P(xi)=yiP(x_i) = y_iP(xi​)=yi​

Let’s see if this is true for the Lagrange polynomial we just found.

In the above equation for ci(x)c_i(x)ci​(x), setting x=xix=x_ix=xi​ and x=xjx=x_jx=xj​, i≠ji \ne ji=j, we have

ci(xi)=∏j=0j≠in(xi−xj)(xi−xj)=1c_i\left( x_i \right) = \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x_i-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} = 1ci​(xi​)=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(xi​−xj​)​=1

and

ci(xj)=∏j=0j≠in(xj−xj)(xi−xj)=0 , j≠ic_i\left( x_j \right) = \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x_j-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} = 0\ ,\ j \neq ici​(xj​)=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(xj​−xj​)​=0 , j=i

Now, using the equation of P(x)P(x)P(x) for x=xix=x_ix=xi​:

P(xi)=c0(xi)y0+...+ci(xi)yi+...+cn(xi)yn=0+...+1⋅yi+...+0=yi\begin{aligned} P(x_i) &= c_0(x_i)y_0 & &+ ... + c_i(x_i)y_i & &+ ... + c_n(x_i)y_n \\ &= 0 & &+ ... + 1\cdot y_i & &+ ... + 0 \\ &= y_i \end{aligned}P(xi​)​=c0​(xi​)y0​=0=yi​​​+...+ci​(xi​)yi​+...+1⋅yi​​​+...+cn​(xi​)yn​+...+0​

Lagrange polynomial — Example

Consider the following dataset. We have 444 data points so the degree of the Lagrange polynomial P(x)P(x)P(x) will be n=3n=3n=3.

xix_ixi​
000
101010
202020
303030
yiy_iyi​
−250-250−250
000
505050
−100-100−100

We first write 444 cardinal functions corresponding to these 444 data points using x-values.

c0(x) = (x−10)(0−10)⋅(x−20)(0−20)⋅(x−30)(0−30) = −16000x3+1100x2−1160x+1c1(x) = (x−0)(10−0)⋅(x−20)(10−20)⋅(x−30)(10−30) = 12000x3−140x2+310xc2(x) = (x−0)(20−0)⋅(x−10)(20−10)⋅(x−30)(20−30) = −12000x3+150x2−320xc3(x) = (x−0)(30−0)⋅(x−10)(30−10)⋅(x−20)(30−20) = 16000x3−1200x2+130x\begin{aligned} c_0(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-10)}{(0-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(0-20)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(0-30)} \ = \ \frac{-1}{6000}x^3 + \frac{1}{100}x^2 - \frac{11}{60} x + 1\\ c_1(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(10-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(10-20)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(10-30)} \ = \ \frac{1}{2000}x^3 - \frac{1}{40}x^2 + \frac{3}{10} x\\ c_2(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(20-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-10)}{(20-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(20-30)} \ = \ \frac{-1}{2000}x^3 + \frac{1}{50}x^2 - \frac{3}{20} x\\ c_3(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(30-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-10)}{(30-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(30-20)} \ = \ \frac{1}{6000}x^3 - \frac{1}{200}x^2 + \frac{1}{30} x \end{aligned}c0​(x) c1​(x) c2​(x) c3​(x) ​= (0−10)(x−10)​⋅(0−20)(x−20)​⋅(0−30)(x−30)​ = 6000−1​x3+1001​x2−6011​x+1= (10−0)(x−0)​⋅(10−20)(x−20)​⋅(10−30)(x−30)​ = 20001​x3−401​x2+103​x= (20−0)(x−0)​⋅(20−10)(x−10)​⋅(20−30)(x−30)​ = 2000−1​x3+501​x2−203​x= (30−0)(x−0)​⋅(30−10)(x−10)​⋅(30−20)(x−20)​ = 60001​x3−2001​x2+301​x​

We then use these four cardinal functions along with the y-values yiy_iyi​ in the equation of P(x)P(x)P(x):

P(x)=c0(x)y0+c1(x)y1+...+cn(x)yn=−x2+35x−250\begin{aligned} P(x) &= c_0(x)y_0 + c_1(x)y_1 + ... + c_n(x)y_n \\ &= -x^2 + 35x -250 \end{aligned}P(x)​=c0​(x)y0​+c1​(x)y1​+...+cn​(x)yn​=−x2+35x−250​

Download file lagrange_polynomial.py from myCourses to plot these points and the interpolation function to check if it works.

Curve fitting

  • If data is obtained experimentally, there could be random noise present due to measurement errors.
    • Interpolation would not be a good choice as it would fit all data points including noise as well.
  • Instead, we use curve fitting, to find a smooth curve that fits the “average” of the data points, and that is less affected by the noise or “outlier” points.

Linear regression

  • Linear regression is a simpler case of curve fitting where a straight line is found that fits a set of data points.

  • Unlike interpolation, the line need not pass through the points.

  • Linear regression line is given by f(x)=ax+bf(x) = ax + bf(x)=ax+b, where aaa is the slope of the line, and bbb is the y-intercept.

  • The main task will be to find aaa and bbb such that the line “fits” the data points in the “best” possible way.

How to determine the “best” fit?

  • To know how good a line fits the given data points, we compute error for each data point.

  • Error is defined as the squared difference between the actual y-value yiy_iyi​ and the y-value given by the regression line, f(xi)f(x_i)f(xi​).

  • The total error EEE for all data points is given by

    E(a,b)=∑i=0n(yi−f(xi))2=∑i=0n(yi−(axi+b))2\begin{aligned} E(a, b) &= \sum_{i=0}^{n} \left ( y_i - f\left ( x_i \right ) \right ) ^ 2 \\ &= \sum_{i=0}^{n} \left ( y_i - \left ( ax_i + b \right ) \right ) ^ 2 \end{aligned}E(a,b)​=i=0∑n​(yi​−f(xi​))2=i=0∑n​(yi​−(axi​+b))2​

  • One way to define “best” fit:

    • Given all the data points (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​), we want to find a line (i.e. find aaa and bbb) such that the error E(a,b)E(a, b)E(a,b) is minimized.

  • To find aaa and bbb that minimize E(a,b)E(a, b)E(a,b), we calculate the partial derivatives of EEE with respect to aaa and bbb:

∂E∂a=0,     ∂E∂b=0\frac{\partial E}{\partial a} = 0,\, \, \, \, \, \frac{\partial E}{\partial b} = 0∂a∂E​=0,∂b∂E​=0

Calculating the partial derivatives

∂E∂a=∑i=0n2(yi−(axi+b))(−xi)\frac{\partial E}{\partial a} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} 2 (y_i - (ax_i + b)) (-x_i)∂a∂E​=i=0∑n​2(yi​−(axi​+b))(−xi​)
∂E∂b=∑i=0n2(yi−(axi+b))\frac{\partial E}{\partial b} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} 2 (y_i - (ax_i + b))∂b∂E​=i=0∑n​2(yi​−(axi​+b))

Setting above derivatives to 000 and solving for aaa and bbb,

a=∑(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)∑(xi−xˉ)2a = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x}) (y_i - \bar{y}) } {\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2 }a=∑(xi​−xˉ)2∑(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​)​
b=yˉ−axˉb = \bar{y} - a\bar{x}b=yˉ​−axˉ

where xˉ\bar{x}xˉ and yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ are the averages of x-values and y-values of data points.

Finally, using these aaa and bbb, we get the desired best-fit line as f(x)=ax+bf(x)=ax+bf(x)=ax+b. Here aaa is slope of the line and bbb is the y-intercept.
